title: Here is a reading list of 20 articles up to 2019 that focus on the analysis of political text using natural language processing (NLP). This list includes papers from both the NLP and political science communities
note: covering topics such as topic detection, stance detection, and election prediction:

title: Text as Data: The Promise and Pitfalls of Automatic Content Analysis Methods for Political Texts
container-title: *Political Analysis*

title: A Method of Automated Nonparametric Content Analysis for Social Science
container-title: *American Journal of Political Science*

title: Measuring Group Differences in High-Dimensional Choices: Method and Application to Congressional Speech
container-title: *Econometrica*

title: Latent Dirichlet Allocation
container-title: *Journal of Machine Learning Research*

title: stm: R Package for Structural Topic Models
container-title: *Journal of Statistical Software*

title: Extracting Policy Positions from Political Texts Using Words as Data
container-title: *American Political Science Review*

title: Classifying Party Affiliation from Political Speech
container-title: *Journal of Information Technology & Politics*

title: Political Polarization on Twitter
container-title: *Proceedings of the Fifth International AAAI Conference on Weblogs and Social Media*

title: Predicting Elections with Twitter: What 140 Characters Reveal about Political Sentiment
container-title: *Proceedings of the Fourth International AAAI Conference on Weblogs and Social Media*

title: From Tweets to Polls: Linking Text Sentiment to Public Opinion Time Series
container-title: *Proceedings of the Fourth International AAAI Conference on Weblogs and Social Media*

title: Political Ideology Detection Using Recursive Neural Networks
container-title: *Proceedings of the 52nd Annual Meeting of the Association for Computational Linguistics*

title: Measuring Ideological Proportions in Political Speeches
container-title: *Proceedings of the 2013 Conference on Empirical Methods in Natural Language Processing*

title: Predicting Legislative Roll Calls from Text
container-title: *Proceedings of the 28th International Conference on Machine Learning*

title: Tea Party in the House: A Hierarchical Ideal Point Topic Model and Its Application to Republican Legislators in the 112th Congress
container-title: *Proceedings of the 53rd Annual Meeting of the Association for Computational Linguistics*

title: Get Out the Vote: Determining Support or Opposition from Congressional Floor-Debate Transcripts
container-title: *Proceedings of the 2006 Conference on Empirical Methods in Natural Language Processing*

title: The Media Frames Corpus: Annotations of Frames Across Issues
container-title: *Proceedings of the 53rd Annual Meeting of the Association for Computational Linguistics*

title: Crowd-sourced Text Analysis: Reproducible and Agile Production of Political Data
container-title: *American Political Science Review*

title: Measuring Emotion in Parliamentary Debates with Automated Textual Analysis
container-title: *PLoS ONE*

title: How Censorship in China Allows Government Criticism but Silences Collective Expression
container-title: *American Political Science Review*

title: When Politicians Talk: Assessing Online Conversational Practices of Political Parties on Twitter
container-title: *Proceedings of the Eighth International AAAI Conference on Weblogs and Social Media*

title: These articles provide a comprehensive overview of the intersection between NLP and political science, offering insights into various methodologies and applications in the analysis of political texts
